unnormalised: **Telecommunications: Fiber-to-Home Expansion Gains Momentum in India**
normalised: **telecommunications: fiber-to-home expansion gains momentum in india**

unnormalised: New Delhi – The rapid expansion of Fiber-to-the-Home (FTTH) infrastructure across India continues apace, driven by increased demand for high-speed internet and the government's BharatNet initiative. Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (TRAI) data released today, 16/10/2024, indicates a significant surge in FTTH subscriptions, particularly in Tier II and Tier III cities.
normalised: new delhi – the rapid expansion of fiber-to-the-home (f t t h) infrastructure across india continues apace, driven by increased demand for high-speed internet and the government's bharatnet initiative. telecom regulatory authority of india (t r a i) data released today, sixteenth october two thousand and twenty four, indicates a significant surge in f t t h subscriptions, particularly in tier two and tier three cities.

unnormalised: Reliance Jio and Airtel are leading the charge, investing heavily in laying optical fiber cables, with Jio recently announcing plans to connect an additional 100,000 km of rural areas by 2025. This expansion promises to bring digital connectivity to previously underserved communities, enabling access to online education, healthcare, and e-commerce opportunities. The "Digital India" vision aims to bridge the digital divide, ensuring every Indian citizen, from Kashmir to Kanyakumari, has access to reliable and affordable internet.
normalised: reliance jio and airtel are leading the charge, investing heavily in laying optical fiber cables, with jio recently announcing plans to connect an additional one hundred thousand kilometer of rural areas by two thousand and twenty five. this expansion promises to bring digital connectivity to previously underserved communities, enabling access to online education, healthcare, and e-commerce opportunities. the "digital india" vision aims to bridge the digital divide, ensuring every indian citizen, from kashmir to kanyakumari, has access to reliable and affordable internet.

unnormalised: Experts predict that FTTH subscriptions will surpass traditional broadband connections by the end of FY25. Challenges remain, including right-of-way approvals and infrastructure costs. A roundtable discussion is scheduled for 20/10/2024 at 11:00 hrs at IIT-Delhi to address these challenges and foster collaboration between government, industry, and academia. Investments are expected to cross Rs. 50,000 Crore in the coming year alone. Further updates are expected on Diwali, 31/10/2024.
normalised: experts predict that f t t h subscriptions will surpass traditional broadband connections by the end of f y twenty five. challenges remain, including right-of-way approvals and infrastructure costs. a roundtable discussion is scheduled for twentieth october two thousand and twenty four at eleven zero zero hours at i i t-delhi to address these challenges and foster collaboration between government, industry, and academia. investments are expected to cross rupee fifty thousand crore in the coming year alone. further updates are expected on diwali, thirty first october two thousand and twenty four.
